playbooks/test-bifrost.yaml.message: Could this just be added to the inventory file?

Right, we should probably get rid of test-bifrost completely, but that's an ambitious goal (and contradicts the other your suggestion). I tried that and got stuck into too many things to move around, so I'm trying smaller steps.

Users would execute a sequence of commands, such as:

ansible-playbook -vvvv -i inventory/target install.yaml

export BIFROST_INVENTORY_SOURCE=/tmp/baremetal.json
ansible-playbook -vvvv -i inventory/bifrost_inventory.py enroll-dynamic.yaml

ansible-playbook -vvvv -i inventory/bifrost_inventory.py deploy-dynamic.yaml

I wouldn't say it contradicts the other suggestion. We would just have a set of separate test playbooks that get executed at the correct stage.

Understood about evolving. In that case, could we simply add an extra -i inventory/target instead of add_host?
You mean, update bifrost_inventory.py? Could be done, although I'm not sure about potential side effects on people using bifrost_inventory.py in their playbooks. Thoughts?
Well, what I have here is the closest to what users would do (i.e. define target to something).

We should really test whatever it is that users are expected to do. When using install.yaml, they are instructed to use the inventory in inventory/target. Maybe we need to split this into the separate commands that users would run.

Because you haven't post-fixed the regexes, this will match on any option starting with the regex string. For example:

  >>> import re
  >>> rex = re.compile('host')
  >>> rex.match('hostname')

hooks/percona_hooks.py.message: Per suggestion made on hooks/percona_utils.py, this would return a dict, empty or not. Depending on the returned value, the following chunk of code would be run (or not).

I think "kvstore = kv()" should be called before the try-except so the ADD_APT_REPOSITORY_FAILED key can be unset if "update_source" succeeded.

For what I can see, the key is set in the "except" scope, but it is never cleared anywhere.
Thanks, I didn't realize that unitdata is stored forever, not just when these hooks are running.

I think assess_status should always be called. The condition (ADD_APT_REPOSITORY_FAILED is True) should be evaluated in assess_status and do nothing (ie. leave the unit in blocked state).

The purpose of that func (assess_status) is to evaluate if the unit status needs to be changed. If multiple keys are created in the future, it would be better to evaluate all the keys within assess_status and not in the main() func.

I think this initialization should be inside the "if new_source" scope. In the current setup, the following could happen: 1) user sets a wrong repo (failed=True), 2) user changes a different config parameter, so "if new_source" is False, but the failed=False initialization will allow assess_status to say "Unit is ready" and go to active/idle state.

I think you are partially right, but also need to move the return out of the catch because:
1) user set a wrong source
2) the user changes to a different configuration and the status changes to "maintenance (config-changed) ..."

I missed this comment on my previous review.
status_set should be called here, before "update_source", instead of calling it from the update_source helper function.

The reason is that it is preferable that any communication via the Juju agent should happen on the hooks script. The utils script should have helper function to set a configuration or return a value (logging inside the utils helper functions is fine, though).
same here. The status_set call to block the unit should be called from here. The goal is to have all communications with Juju on the hooks script.
We forgot to flush (save it) after setting the variable in kvstore.

We want to separate helper functions (in utils.py) from Juju communication calls.
same about this call. It should be moved to the hooks.py script.

I'm a little unsure about this.  I think it should at least also set the status to a blocked message as this may be in the assess status hook.  Is it clear that nothing else should be done in the assess_status call?

It is assumed that the status was previously set at https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/charm-percona-cluster/+/refs/changes/47/762147/5/hooks/percona_hooks.py#552

tempest/scenario/test_aggregates_basic_o.message:
I was debating here should fail or skip. In our gate CI, I think the test should be failed because it shouldn't be happened and we likely miss the skipped tests. On the other hand, in the downstream test CI cases, I'm not sure. But I guess this should be passed in most case. I think skip condition should depend on configs or settings not on runtime states basically.

Is this just over-thinking?

Rick and I talked. 
I also agree if we need to skip items we need to support more of a conf direction so it support both upstream and downstream CI.

With that said I do not see enough value to this scenario since the api test_aggregates [0] does test the API for aggregates and aggregates metadata.

With that said I would suggest that we blacklist this test in our downstream CI and abandon this commit if all agree.
 
[0] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/api/compute/admin/test_aggregates.py

I think skipping is the correct behavior because this is an environmental prerequisite issue that isn't satisfied. The test itself shouldn't fail because it can't find a suitable host for testing. That doesn't mean that the test in and of itself failed, only that it cannot pass under the given environmental circumstances.

If we do want it to fail, it would require throwing a specific error as to why it failed: namely, that no available host could be found for the test to run. But again, I think that this should be a skip, not a fail.

Here is the example I followed: https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/api/compute/admin/test_aggregates.py#L220 ... I found this when searching for bug reports for the same situation we were coming across. As seen in that example, the skip is based on runtime state. I agree with Doug about the limited value this scenario test provides. I just wanted to point out that there is another example of an aggregate test skipping based on runtime state.
Good Question.  Let me talk to Rick on this one some more

I'd like to raise skipException in this case.
Yes for ci environments, it's almost impossible to encounter "all hosts have been added to other zone", but in production cloud environments, we can't estimate what our customers will do, and usually no fail testcase is allowed, so, if one testcase fails just because they put all hosts into specific zones, we will have much trouble to explain it:)
Thanks for the review. I also see it the same way that the test should support production environments. For this particular test, I do not see how the skip can come from configuration.

doc/source/configuration/block-storage/d.message:
My $0.02 here: in Kolla we rely on Ceph client libraries versions supplied by CentOS/Ubuntu/Debian, and in a lot of cases operators run newer/older Ceph cluster (server) than the client version - and that's totally fine.
I don't see an issue with claiming that mixing versions may lead to anomalous behaviour - but since Cinder uses RBD, and there's very few features that render client incompatible - I would say it would be better to encourage users to use the same client and server version, than to say it's unsupported.
Sometimes they don't have the control over client library version (e.g. Kolla containers that use distro-provided packages) or server version (externally delivered service etc).
Have you had any bugs/support queries related to ceph client libraries being 1/2 releases older than the cluster they were connecting to?

There are multiple reasons to require alignment:
- Without it system could be using a Luminous client without support for a Mimic feature that Cinder wants to use.
- If an older client has a known bug that won't be fixed because that longer is no longer supported we would have to include a workaround in Cinder.
- Backward compatibility at the CLI level doesn't necessarily mean backward compatibility at the library level.
- As far as I know, the CI uses aligned versions, so that's what we can be sure works.

I'm sure there are other reasons.

Thanks for the comment, Michal, but I agree with everything Gorka said.  The primary concern for me is the CI, which does use aligned versions, so we have no way (other than waiting for a user to file a bug) to discover that misalignment is causing a problem.

My understanding of the Wallaby PTG discussion was that we don't have plans to enforce alignment in the code, so it leaves the possibility open for some downstream distro to appropriately test and support unaligned client/server versions, if that would be useful for their customers.  But as far as we're concerned upstream, such a configuration is unsupported.

I'd say "IPv6 will be disabled on the container DHCP network (undercloud) ...".

Initially, I misinterpreted this statement as disabling IPv6 on the host LXD is getting configured, which is not the case. The following is ok:
"""
$ sysctl net.ipv6.conf.lxdbr0.disable_ipv6
net.ipv6.conf.lxdbr0.disable_ipv6 = 0
"""

But from the LXD interface, the following will be run (seen below in this doc):
lxc network unset lxdbr0 ipv6.address
lxc network unset lxdbr0 ipv6.nat
So just insert "DHCP" in the sentence?
Thanks. I will reword but I do want to say *why* we're disabling it.
Yes, something along the lines: "IPv6 will be disabled on the container DHCP network (undercloud) to make both underlay and overlay networks use IPv4".

I think this section since line 198 should be part of the section that starts at line 181 ("Configure the LXD network as described earlier:").

This chapter is about:
1) Initialize configuration
2) Manual step to configure the network
3) Manual step to configure the storage

Anything related to network should be in section #2.
OK I see now. I'll think of something.
That cannot be done because LXD is not initialised until line 175. The lxdbr0 bridge will not exist yet.

Indeed, line 175 is where "lxd init --auto" is called. Then, several network configurations are applied. Then, a storage configuration is applied. Then, another network configuration is applied.

What I'd suggest is add the last network config at the end of the previous network configs (after line 188).

This should be explicit. I can't find "apt-deb-proxy" as an Ubuntu package at:
https://packages.ubuntu.com/search?keywords=apt-deb-proxy&searchon=names&suite=all&section=all

"apt-cacher" package does exist, but the purpose of that service is to make all nodes point to the one running apt-cacher (for caching of external mirrors).

Maybe "squid" should be recommended, which does not listen on port 8000 by default (only maas proxy, which runs squid underneath is configured on port 8000).

On the other hand, these are the supported Juju apt proxy parameters:
"""
$ juju model-defaults | egrep apt
apt-ftp-proxy                 ""                       -
apt-http-proxy                ""                       -
apt-https-proxy               ""                       -
apt-mirror                    ""                       -
apt-no-proxy                  ""                       -
"""

The reader of this doc should know that config.yaml should have apt-http-proxy pointing to the proxy service configured (by the person using openstack-on-lxd or by their proxy provider [ie. company proxy]).

Maybe also advice about "juju model-defaults" and juju-http-proxy, juju-https-proxy and juju-no-proxy variables. If set as default, any addition of new models will use them.

specs/wallaby/backlog/cinder-ceph-replic.message: I propose we extend the current ceph-access relation instead, see below.

I have a couple of issues with this approach.

1) This would require the end user of the charms to add a second relation both for cinder-ceph and nova-compute charms.

2) Creating two almost identical relations lead to unnecessary code duplication in the charms.

Suggestion:
Add support for distributing multiple keys in the current ceph-access relation.

This can be done in a backwards compatible way by populating the current `key` + `secret-uuid` relation keys with the first Ceph key and creating a new data structure that contains all keys (For example `secrets` which contains a JSON encoded List[Dict[str,str]])

The receiving end will then look for the new data structure and use that when present and fall back to using the `key` + `secret-uuid` keys when the new data structure is not present.

This is how it looks in terms of code implementation:
* cinder-ceph: https://github.com/ionutbalutoiu/charm-cinder-ceph/commit/e752d794cc3e82fdbe378b0a39593e7d24f374d8#diff-011cde7a1fc79f74d8ad066a1e8f7fcb9783e7dd3d75b599a90b79d2171a4b01R419 (where `app_name` is defined before the `relation_set` call)
* nova-compute: https://github.com/ionutbalutoiu/charm-nova-compute/commit/78acc4fa058f2a346b5f83fd1d5049f42e4c8575#diff-3858bce810b0db33ad1f0b0daaa7204dcd80f14a39a9f5712f0a189c1c99c5b4

Makes sense what you point out.

But I think that limitation applies now as well. If there's another app from another model relating, it will still overwrite the nova-compute Ceph keyring (if there's an app already related with the same name in the current model).

With the update proposed here, at least we take care of the apps deployed in the same model.

And, we need to take care of Nova Ceph access to the replication backend. Otherwise, the Cinder volumes cannot be attached to VMs after a failover happened.

Yes I agree that you're already improving things and that you're not introducing a regression. 

Yet it might be easy to take "modelname+applicationname" and have then the edge case covered, but I'm not sure myself. Let's see what others say.

I have an issue with creating a separate relation for this, please see above.

Neither model name nor application name is unique. Since cinder-ceph already has a unique UUID per secret perhaps we could use that in the filename?

For backwards compatibility use the old naming scheme when there is only one key, and use the new naming scheme when there are multiple keys.

That's an option to avoid that edge case, I agree.

I'm open for suggestions.

This makes sense, thanks, in theory though with cross-model relations we could still have two applications with the same name. We might not want to support this edge case though. I'll ask for another opinion.

change the % here to ,

_LE(), {"error": 

Also should probably change the str(e) to six.text_type(e)
six.text_type not needed here, please remove.
does _LE do the six.text_type(var) internally before translating it?

No, the translation markers don't have anything to do with it. The logger will actually take care of it internally.

So for any logger call that does LOG.blah(FORMAT_STRING % ex) there is an issue because the string formatting is happening first, then being passed in to the logger. In that case you need six.text_type.

But if it is LOG.blah(FORMAT_STRING, ex) then ex is just passed in as an argument to the logger and the logger can take care of it if and when it needs to.

I have some comments regarding this function implementation:

1/ I think it'd be better to do not modify the `reviewers` argument inside. Instead, let's return a new one with new values, and do below something like:

  options.reviewers = expand_reviewers(options.reviewers)

2/ You call `git_config_get_value` twice. Each time you call the `git` command is executed. Let's decrease number of third-party command execution. Save its result somewhere and use it later.

3/ I don't like that you iterate over reviewers and change it at once. For example, I don't know whether it affects the following iteration or not. If you implement the (1) comment, code readability will be increased.
Done

There can be dead loop if someone set the same name for the group of reviewers and for a reviewer inside this group.
Please check that any value of the list git_config_get_value("reviewers", r).split() doesn't match the group name: r .
I don't think the dead-loop is possible. The function doesn't use recursion.
Done
Done

Recursion confirmed with

git config --global reviewers.recursion "test@recursion recursion"

git review --reviewers recursion
Done

you can simplify the code a bit by using:

  members = git_config_get_value("reviewers", r, default=[r])

and the code becomes:

  configs = (git_config_get_value("reviewers", r, default=[r]) for r in reviewers)
  return [m for config in configs for m in configs.split()]
thanks, nice way

would be good to do the same check when getting reviewers from config file as from command line (make sure no spaces in the string).

Also how about duplicate reviewers?  for example what if user defines 'johnd@gmail' in 'myteam' then 'git review --reviewers johnd@gmail.com myteam'?
@Khai, I use space as delimiter in the config and return list of strings. And therefore expand_reviewers will return user without spaces

Ok about duplicate user case.   The  'assert_valid_reviewers' method says that whitespace in reviewer name will result in invalid respec.   I'm saying that we should also check for that when getting names from config file.

Where spaces do you mean? In account name? If somebody put space in name, git-review send it as two users. Gerrit doesn't accept request with users who are absent.

If we send duplicates users Gerrit will ignore duplicate
sorry, i should have read that git_config_get_value method more carefully. looks good.

I wonder if it would be better to periodically query the southbound database and update neutron database in a single transaction instead of handling individual updates to entries in the chassis table. As the number of ovn-controllers starts to grows, more individual commits would be needed.
Also, we need to elected a single neutron-server (like we do for maintenance and ovsdb monitor, this can be done using ovsdb naming locks as well) to handle the agents status update in Neutron.
Thanks Lucas. This is a very good suggestion. I will use this.

An alternative to consider for ovn-controller would be to use the cfg variables in the northbound and southbound dbs as a type of health check.  networking-ovn could udpate the nb_cfg at some interval.  It can then look at how that number is propagated as a type of health check.

sb_cfg (in the nb db) -- an indication that ovn-northd has properly synced with the current nb db

hv_cfg (in the nb db) -- an indication of the latest version that all ovn-controllers for all Chassis in the sb db have synced with

If hv_cfg != sb_cfg, then you can look into the sb db to figure out which Chassis is not (yet) in sync.

Gotcha, yeah agreed about leaving the cleaning bits out.

Perhaps we can just go with the:

1. Update the nb_cfg in NB DB
2. Loop thru the chassis and check if that nb_cfg in the SB DB is >= the value you updated.

This would be faster and more lightweight than the current proposal of adding a timestamp in all chassis' external_ids and comparing it.

I remember reading about those *_cfg flags in the OVN man pages. I quite like the idea of using it as lightweight mechanism to detect if something is wrong before performing a "heavier" operation.

Question: If a ovn-controller dies abruptly and doesn't remove itself from the Chassis table in the SB DB database, the "hv_cfg" will always be lower than "sb_cfg". Should networking-ovn take care of automatically cleaning the Chassis entry in the SB DB when a chassis which is still registered is marked as being down ?
Thanks a lot Russel. I was not aware of these fields. I will use this approach.

regarding hv_cfg -- you're right, it will only be updated when everything is healthy.  Otherwise, you need to look at per-hv values in the sb db.

Regarding chassis cleanup, it's probably worth thinking about some more, but I wouldn't want to wrap it up with this proposal necessarily.
In reference implementation cleaning up dead agent is responsibility of the admin. So we will leave it.

We've seen significant scale issues with every node reporting state via RPC to neutron-servers. Sometimes the cluster has a performance hiccup due to whatever reason (legit workflow spike, bug in some service that causes CPU starvation, whatever) which causes the agents to either report state too slowly or for the neutron-server to process the reports too slowly, and the queue increasing in size. At that point the operator sometimes has to get out of this jam manually and meanwhile we see control plane outage due to the OVS agent being "down" and port bindings failing.

All to say that the scalability of the new mechanism is important. I'd be curious to learn from the ODL community - Have they seen any issues with their approach, any scale testing done there.

Whatever approach we end up taking in OVN I think it should pend on scale testing before merge.
Thanks Assaf, in this spec we are avoiding RPC approach and instead going with SBDB update events.

I agree with Numan/Assaf. I understand that using the RPC implementation is default and probably easier to implement but, adding a new dependency just for the sake of reporting the status seems a bit overkill.

Also, one of the pros of ML2/OVN vs ML/OVS is the fact that we don't rely on rabbit, is a very convincing argument for OVN's promoting. In the last performance report about OVN from joe (rook) one of the main points he made is that we saw a 700% process saving when using ML2/OVN instead of ML2/OVS and that's a big win.
I agree with Numan, introducing the RPC bus as a new dependency of OVN is a huge change, let's find a way to avoid that.

Rabbitmq approach is very easy and small code change(similar to ml2/OVS metadta agent implementation). As rabbitmq is already configured in the hypervisors for nova compute, we can reuse that.

With the RPC approach, we can avoid introducing load on OVSDB server for periodic OVSDB updates.

One note here is that we don't have an automatic mechanism to clean up the chassis table if a controller dies abruptly. So, probably after the first controller goes down this optimization won't work anymore (unless someone cleans the chassis table manually or the controller comes back on). 

So, maybe, for the sake of an easier implementation and code readability, we could just skip this item and always look at each hypervisor's nb_cfg all the time. If it turns to be a problem later we can go ahead and optimize it in a smarter way (e.g having the chassis table automatically cleaned up and so on).

Agreed that if a node goes down, admin would work on fixing it, but we need to consider a scenario wherein the hypervisor is alive but the ovn-controller is not responding ( for example, due to lack of inodes, or some network failure or some other case ). Would this logic still be aplicable?

Usually when a node goes down, admin will be fixing it as early as possible, so we can assume that nodes will be active most of the time. In this case, this optimisation helps avoiding reading all chassis records from chassis table.

specs/victoria/approved/filter-instances.message: Nova support filtering by project_id. The project terminology is replaced the old tenant terminology across OpenStack but the data behind the project_id is the same as it was behind the tenant_id. So I think nova has the requested capability already, via the project_id filtering.

> I agree with gibi, we only support the 'tenant' name for the
 > existing APIs.

I think gibi's mean that we should only support filter/show 'project'/'project_id'in our interface, not 'tenant'.
So my goal would be to remove the inconsistency. I think the end result of that work should be that we only have project and project_id in our interface.

As I said in Alternative, if we want to only use "project_id", that we should discard ``tenant_id``, For our customer, they are not want to see this.

Inconsistency of compute api, openstack command and nova command commands:

Compute API: list servers API cannot support the "tenant_id" as a filter parameter, but it can filter the instances by "project_id".

Nova command:"nova list --tenant <project> " can get the expected instances, it used tenant as the parameter.

OpenStack command: "openstack server list --project <project>" using the project as the filter parameter.
I agree with gibi, we only support the 'tenant' name for the existing APIs.

ironic/drivers/modules/ansible/network.p.message: ansible-runner is the recommended way by the ansible community to do this. We use ansible in network-runner: https://github.com/ansible-network/network-runner/blob/devel/network_runner/api.py#L59

This class is doing very similar thinks to the NetworkRunner class in the network-runner project. Main differences seem that this one has ironic conventions and expects a playbook passed to it. NR constructs a playbook and is not ironic specific. I'd be curious to try and meld these together to offer some easy interfacing and some flexibility.

https://github.com/ansible-network/network-runner/blob/devel/network_runner/api.py#L34

right, I wasn't proposing to get rid of it. That may not have been clear the way I put my comment. I was intending to suggest we could map these functions to those in network-runner since they should align well with each other.
